citeinfo.origin: Center for Historical Geography, Fudan University
citeinfo.title: CHGIS China Coastline, 1820

descript.abstract: The polylines in this datalayer represent the costline of mainland China in the year 1820.The CHGIS will establish a database of historical administrative units, as well as other features, for different periods in Chinese History, and will also provide a base GIS platform for researchers to use for spatial analysis, temporal statistical modeling, and representation of selected historical units as digital maps.
descript.purpose: Developed by Fudan University, Center for Historical Geography, for the CHGIS project.The CHGIS project is designed to provide a GIS platform for scholarly and scientific research. Considerable flexibility has been designed into the GIS, allowing for alternate versions and variations of feature attributes, spatial data, and competing political entities. The CHGIS aims to build a reliable database of administrative units, but does not wish to impose a closed interpretation on the relationships among those units. The advantage of creating the CHGIS, rather than printing paper maps, is that the relationships between the units can be modified and improved whenever new information becomes available and the new "edition" needs only to be posted on the Internet for users to download. The CHGIS editors have set high editorial standards for the inclusion of material in the CHGIS data products and regulate the release of the official versions from designated CHGIS participating organizations.Users may search the database for settlements, administrative units and capitals, can create customized digital maps for particular times and places, or can join their own datasets for spatial anaysis, thematic mapping, or other specialized statistical modeling according to their own interests.
descript.supplinf: The names of populated places in the CHGIS dataset are represented by both Chinese characters and Pinyin. Chinese characters may not display properly on machines without the proper character sets installed.UTF-8 Encoding is employed for Chinese characters.

idinfo.accconst: The CHGIS datasets are freely distributed for non-commercial academic research purposes. The datasets may be obtained by ordering a CD-ROM or downloaded free of charge from the CHGIS website.Please consult the website (http://fas.harvard.edu/~chgis) for additional details.
idinfo.useconst: Academic use of CHGIS data is allowed, and encouraged, provided that any derived data or digital images of maps give proper citation to CHGIS as stated above. The CHGIS datasets are distributed for non-commercial academic research purposes only. Any organization or individual that makes commercial or revenue generating use of the CHGIS Datasets must first obtain a licensing agreement from CHGIS Management Committee. Use of the datasets distributed on CD-ROM or downloaded from CHGIS websites implies acceptance of all the terms stated in the End User's License Agreement, and acknowledges understanding of any liabilities stated therein by the end-user.

cntinfo.hours: Monday through Friday 9:00 A.M. to 4:00 P.M. EST-USA

idinfo.datacred: CHGIS, Version: 1.0. Cambridge, MA (USA): Harvard Yenching Institute, April 2002 (Revised May, 2003)
idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows NT Version 4.0 (Build 1381) Service Pack 6; ESRI ArcCatalog 8.2.0.700

dataqual.complete: The project begins with the publication of CHGIS Version 1.0, which contains datasets for the year 1820 (Qing Dynasty). Following this release, the project will work backwards, creating a continuous time series of records that track changes in placename, administrative status, and geography.

horizpa.horizpar: The CHGIS historical coastline conforms for the most part with the Digital Map Database of China (DMDC) coastline, but due to certain historical factors, there are several dramatic differences. Hydrologic activity, such as flooding and silting have altered, often dramatically, the shape and extent of the Chinese coastline.

srcinfo.srccontr: The national level CHGIS datasets for the year 1820 are based on materials that were used in the production of the "Historical Atlas of China," Volume 8 (1987) edited by Tan Qixiang. The national boundaries strictly follow those shown in the Tan's Atlas while some of the settlement points (called "populated places") as well as polylines representing prefecture borders and rivers have been edited to reflect evidence in historical sources and to properly mesh with the correct positions of natural features.

citeinfo.origin: National Bureau of Surveying and Mapping (NBSM)
citeinfo.title: 1:1,000,000 Scale Topographic Map of China

pubinfo.publish: National Bureau of Surveying and Mapping (NBSM)

citeinfo.othercit: Each map sheet covers six degrees longitude by four degrees latitude.The 1:1,000,000-scale map series is the smallest National Essential Topographic Map Series in China, which comprehensively depicts the natural, social and economic situation in China and forms a relevant geographic base for many uses.

srcinfo.srccontr: Used for the authoritative basemap for comparison of historical data and rectification.

procstep.procdesc: The CHGIS boundaries are based on Tan's "Historical Atlas of China" Volume 8 (1987). After the initial digitization of the boundaries, they were placed over over Digital Map Database of China (DMDC) data layers and adjusted to conform to the topography, hydrography and coastline of the DMDC basemap.
The CHGIS shapefile was imported to an ArcSDE Layer.
